organization.$: Center of Excellence in Environment and Plant Physiology

head.citation-title: Effects of silver nanoparticles on hydrogen peroxide generation and antioxidant enzyme responses in rice
head.abstracts: Copyright © 2016 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.This research aims to study the effect of different sizes, 20, 30-70, 70-120 and 150 nm, of silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) at 10 mg/L on the antioxidant enzymatic activities of rice (Oryza sativa L. cv. KDML 105) seedlings under normal and salt stress conditions. Seed priming with 10 mg/L of 20-nm-diameter AgNPs leads to the significant enhancement of root growth when rice seedlings were grown in a nutrient solution containing 85 mM NaCl. Because AgNPs are considered oxidative stress generators, it was hypothesized that priming with AgNPs could induce antioxidant enzyme activities in rice seedlings, resulting in the acclimatization to salt stress. An enhancement in the activities of the antioxidant enzymes catalase, superoxide dismutase, ascorbate peroxidase, glutathione reductase and glutathione peroxidase generally occurred in primed seedlings in an AgNPsizedependent manner. AgNPs with 150-nm diameters could induce the highest level of hydrogen peroxide accumulation in both root and shoot tissues of normal and salt-stressed seedlings, as well as the highest level of antioxidant enzymatic activities. The highest growth inhibition was found with the 150-nm AgNP pretreatment. However, AgNPs with 20-nm diameters caused a lower level of hydrogen peroxide accumulation and antioxidant enzymatic activities, except for glutathione reductase, and triggered the earliest responses of the antioxidant enzymes in root or shoot tissues under salt-stress conditions. Thus, the induction response time, rather than the amplitude of the response, was more important in the acclimatization ability to salt stress via, AgNP priming.

organization.$: Center of Excellence in Environment and Plant Physiology
